desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 18 - 25 m tall, trunk diameter 40 cm - 1 m. Trunk straight, crown broadly rounded. Sprouts often found at the base of living trees.

part.partText: brown, thick, deeply furrowed into long, narrow, flat-topped, scaly ridges; ridges nearly parallel, sometimes interlacing.
slender, stout, gray or brown, somewhat zigzagged, smooth. Leaf scars half-elliptical, with 3 or more bundle scars.
lustrous green or reddish brown, 6 mm long, egg-shaped, pointed, lopsided, smooth. Bud scales usually 2.

alternate, stalked, green and smooth above, paler and smooth or with tufts of hair beneath, 12 - 15 or more cm long, 7 - 10 cm wide, obliquely heart-shaped, lobes unequal, base asymmetrical, tip pointed, margins coarsely toothed, thin, firm.

have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); borne in drooping clusters on a long, slender stalk attached to a yellowish, paddle-shaped bract; greenish yellow to white, small, hairy, sepals 5, petals 5, fragrant, insect-pollinated.
a hard, woody nut; in clusters on a long, slender stalk attached to a yellowish, paddle-shaped bract; light brown or gray, 6 mm in diameter, spherical with a short point at the tip, finely hairy.

similarSpecies.comments: Tilia americana differs from T. americana var. heterophylla by the virtual absence of hairs on the underside of its leaves.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Very common in dry to moist woods. Also grows in the dry conditions of high dunes found near Lake Michigan and the steep slopes of riverbanks and ravines.

notes.comments: The wood of Tilia americana is not very durable, but is used for boxes, crates, furniture parts, interior trim, veneer, plywood, pulp, fuel, and hand carving. Although planted as an ornamental, European species are more commonly used. Native Americans made rope from the bark of its young stems.

etymology.comments: Tilia is the Latin name for the linden or basswood tree. Americana means “from America” (North or South).
